Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Region: Accelerating the Adoption of Campus Cyberinfrastructure Technologies in Pennsylvania

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Keystone Initiative for Network Based Education and Research (KINBER), a statewide nonprofit organization, is implementing a program of coordinated leadership and mentoring activities that improve the ability of Pennsylvania colleges and universities to understand and utilize their network infrastructure to support cyberinfrastructure-based scientific applications and research on their campuses. These leadership activities focus on the understanding, deployment, integration and support of campus cyberinfrastructure technologies, such as perfSONAR, campus science DMZ, end-to-end performance monitoring and campus cybersecurity. This program establishes a collaborative cyberinfrastructure community in Pennsylvania through the use of facilitated workshops, campus visits, regional monitoring, follow-up visits and technical assistance including deploying perfSONAR equipment. The program's expanded deployment of perfSONAR platforms within the state provides a rich set of performance measurement and diagnostic tools to campus IT staff and researchers.

The knowledge gained through this program enables campuses within Pennsylvania to support a broad set of cyberinfrastructure-based applications, including those that rely on the seamless integration of computing, storage and network resources, including the ability to support large data transfers. The program provides benefits over the longer term as additional Pennsylvania colleges and universities deploy science DMZs and expand their campus infrastructure capabilities, utilizing the program's online knowledge base for solving and identifying common cyberinfrastructure problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to develop a set of leadership activities that would improve the ability of colleges and universities throughout Pennsylvania to better understand and utilize their network infrastructure to support cyberinfrastructure based scientific research and education applications on their campuses. Project activities focused on  improving the understanding, deployment, integration, and support of campus cyberinfrastructure technologies, such as perfSONAR, campus science DMZ, end-to-end performance monitoring, and campus cybersecurity for a broad set of college and university campuses within Pennsylvania. The intellectual merit associated with the project was to foster a greater level of collaboration within the Pennsylvania higher education community, leveraging the existing expertise of the KINBER staff, providing mentorship and facilitating collaboration among a diverse set of institutions.

 Initially, KINBER focused on: increasing the understanding of cyberinfrastructure technologies; identifing research and science driven applications within the campus environment; and fostering research driven collaboration across constituencies. KINBER then built upon this fundamental understanding of cyberinfrastructure technologies, deepening the level of understanding, deployment and support by a core set of institutions and then broadening the exposure to cyberinfrastructure technologies to additional organizations within the state. During the final project year KINBER strengthened its engagement activities to support advanced cyberinfrastructure awareness at organizations that have received individual CC* awards and also developed an aggregated regional approach to cyberinfrastructure collaboration within the state and among interstate regional entities. The broader impact of the project included understanding and addressing the barriers and challenges to adopting cyberinfrastructure technologies by smaller colleges and universities as well as to foster stronger collaborations across the state and between different constituency groups. The project goals were accomplished through a range of outreach activities including webinars, presentations, and in-person workshops, individual site meetings or campus visits, the KINBER perfSONAR pilot program, and information dissemination. Throughout the project, KINBER opened its activities to organizations, both regional networks and individual campuses, outside of Pennsylvania.

Project outcomes included: identifying common science research or education drivers within and across institutions; reducing barriers to receiving federal funding from agencies such as the NSF; recognizing and addressing the  difficulty small institutions have in submitting successful proposals; and, the development of a regional cyberinfrastructure projects. KINBER’s perfSONAR pilot project resulted in the deployment and adoption of the platform by a number of institutions. Throughout the project period, KINBER worked with schools to understand the value of creating a campus cyberinfrastructure plan to their overall information technology strategy, outside of the proposal development cycle, and emphasizing the role of central IT in guiding a path for research and science in a proactive way rather than reacting to individual research needs. As Pennsylvania's only statewide research, education and community network, other members of KINBER's constituency, such as libraries, K12 entities, and community organizations have been exposed to core technologies associated with the program. A specific example is the KINBER’s perfSONAR based network assessment project for rural Pennsylvania libraries. This project assesses their current local and wide area network connectivity,  identifies connectivity problems and recommends solutions. A final result of the project was the formation of the KINBER Research Engagement Advisory Committee, modeled after those from other states and composed of Pennsylvania CIOs, researchers and others knowledgeable on cyberinfrastructure resources in support of research and education applications.  

As a result of this project, the understanding and adoption of campus cyberinfrastructure technologies as well as the submission of  proposals requesting support for cyberinfrastructure funding in Pennsylvania increased not only among typical research entities but also from organizations not traditionally viewed as research intensive. Types of schools engaged in the program included: research universities such as The Pennsylvania State University, the University of Pittsburgh, and Duquesne University; small and under resourced liberal arts colleges such as Franklin & Marshall College, Bucknell University, University of Scranton, La Salle University, Lafayette College, Arcadia University, Indiana University of Pennsylvania, Millersville University of Pennsylvania; and, community colleges including Community College of Beaver County, Bucks County Community College, Montgomery County Community College, Lehigh Carbon Community College, and Harrisburg Area Community College.  KINBER will continue to integrate support for cyberinfrastructure technologies designed to advance Pennsylvania based research and education applications into its everyday activities.
